title-group.article-title: Holocene subfossil records of the auroch (Bos primigenius) in Romania

author-notes.corresp: Luminita Bejenaru, ‘Alexandru Ioan Cuza’ University, Carol I Bd., 11, Iasi 700506, Romania. Email: lumib@uaic.ro

abstract.p: This paper reviews identification of the auroch (Bos primigenius) during the Holocene in Romania based on data from 190 archaeological sites, corresponding to Neolithic (including Chalcolithic), Bronze Age, Iron Age, Antiquity and the Middle Ages. The assemblages were analysed according to the geographical and historical regionalisation of the Romanian territory (i.e. Moldavia, Dobrudja, Wallachia, Banat, and Transylvania). The data reveal the rather low contribution of hunted aurochs to local economies, though with spatial and temporal variations. Although the species is currently extinct, aurochs still appear in the medieval samples from the 14–15th centuries, and the coincidence of the archaeozoological data with those from documentary sources is marked.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Archaeozoology, the interdisciplinary research of faunal remains recovered from archaeological excavations, aims to identify the relations between animals and human communities (hunting in the case of aurochs), to determine aspects of their shared geographical environment, to estimate species biogeography and dispersal, especially in the case of animals that are extinct such as the aurochs. The polyvalent reconstruction of the way of life within ancient societies is not possible without the reference points provided by archaeozoology in relation to palaeoeconomy and palaeoecology. The written sources concerning the fauna of Romania in medieval times are deficient and ambiguous. Therefore, it is particularly important to thoroughly consider the archaeozoolgical records and to develop a synthetic study of this topic, correlating the auroch’s story with the evolution of human communities in Romania from Neolithic to the Middle Ages. Archaeozoological data collected and analysed are from the Neolithic, rather than from the Mesolithic because of the inconsistency of the references for this period, nevertheless included in Table 1.

caption.p: Frequencies of auroch remains (NISP) in the archaeozoological samples(% NISP among total identified mammals).

tr.td: Necrasov and Bulai-Stirbu (1965); Necrasov and Stirbu (1981)
Necrasov and Bulai-Stirbu (1965); Necrasov and Haimovici (1970)
Balasescu and Radu (2004); Haimovici and Balasescu (2006)
Haimovici and Dardan (1970); Balasescu et al. (2005)
Balasescu and Radu (2004); Balasecu and Udrescu (2005)
Necrasov (1961); El Susi and Rusu (1995); Bindea (2008)

sec.p: The relief of Romania, including the Carpathian Mountains, the Sub-Carpathians, hills, tablelands, plains, river meadows, and the Danube Delta, has structured the climate, soil, vegetation and fauna as well as human settlements. The forests, which up to the Middle Ages covered large areas of Romania, were gradually cleared for farming land. Archaeozoological data evidence that during ancient times, since the Neolithic, animal husbandry was constantly practiced but hunting also kept track of developments through time. Within the group of hunted mammals, the auroch (Bos primigenius) has been identified as contributing to secure food for people in the ancient human settlements.

Originating probably in India (Thenius, 1980), the auroch (Bos primigenius) evolved there between 1.5 and 2 million years ago, and spread in the course of the Pleistocene to the other parts of Asia, to Europe and to northern Africa (Von Koenigswald, 1999). In Europe, during the Pleistocene, the auroch withdrew during cold periods to the Mediterranean area and expanded in warmer periods to the north (Von Koenigswald, 1999). In the early-Holocene fauna, aurochs began to occupy the limited ecological niche of the large (about 1000 kg) ruminants considered mixed feeders (Bos primigenius, Bison bonasus), beside other herbivore associations such as small-sized specialized ruminants (Rupicapra rupicapra, Saiga tatarica etc.), medium–large opportunistic mixed feeders (Cervus elaphus, Dama dama, Rangifer tarandus), large browsers (Alces alces) and small browsers (Capreolus capreolus) (Brugal and Croitor, 2007).

About 9000 years ago, the auroch was domesticated in the Near East (Zeder, 2008), and since then wild and domestic populations were more or less in competition for food and space. Although most studies of mitochondrial DNA show no indication of hybridization between European aurochs (Bos primigenius) and domestic cattle (Bos taurus) (Bollongino et al., 2006; Edwards et al., 2007), nevertheless limited local introgression cattle–aurochs is yet to be determined (Svensson and Götherström, 2008).

During the Mesolithic in Romania, before the arrival of domestic cattle, the auroch probably was an often-hunted species. The proportion of auroch bones among all mammal remains identified in the Mesolithic site of Ostrovul Corbului is 15.4% (Haimovici, 1987a). Later, after the Neolithic, the importance of the auroch was marginal.

Extinction of the auroch in Europe, starting in the southern and western regions, was probably due to habitat fragmentation followed by isolation of populations and the associated risks, as consequence to the increase of human communities. The auroch populations slowly diminished through a combination of factors – competition for food with domestic cattle, cattle diseases, and hunting. The auroch seems to have disappeared from Hungary by the 13th century (Bartosiewicz, 1999), and in late and postmedieval European written records, the auroch appears as special game, the privilege of nobility. The last individual, a cow, died in 1627 in Poland (Heymanowski, 1972).

In Romania, the auroch was the symbol of medieval Moldavia, often represented on seals and coats of arms (Nania, 1991). The auroch has been documented for the earliest periods in all of the main regions, but only in Moldavia (i.e. Siret, Baia), and Transylvania (Simleul Silvaniei) after the 14th–16th centuries. The medieval documents show that the last aurochs vanished from Moldavian fauna probably at the beginning of the 17th century (Nedici, 1940). We can suppose that these aurochs were conteporaneus with the ‘last’ Polish one; there is even an auroch horn core from the 16th–17th centuries from the Princely Court of Suceava in Moldavia. It is known that aurochs at the time visited the lower valleys, closer to human settlements, in their quest for food, causing damage to the crops near the woods during summertime (Filipascu, 1969).

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: This study summarises previous and recent archaeozoological analyses dealing with subsistence practices in the area. The analysis includes 202 faunal assemblages, corresponding to the main pre- and historical ages recognized for Romania: Neolithic – including Chalcolithic (6600–3000/2500 bc), Bronze Age (3000/2500 bc–1200/1150 bc), Iron Age (1200/1150 bc–ad 106), Antiquity (1st–5th centuries), and Middle Ages (6th–16th centuries). The assemblages were grouped according to geographical criteria into the five zones recognized for Romania, namely, Moldavia (eastern Romania), Dobruja (southeastern Romania), Wallachia – including Muntenia & Oltenia (southern Romania), Banat (southwestern Romania) and Transylvania (central and western Romania) (Figure 1).

caption.p: Map of Romania showing the geographical zones.

sec.p: The identification of the archaeozoological material aimed to establish the anatomical and taxonomic origin of the remains according to their morphological characteristics. The separation of aurochs from the domestic form – cattle –was achieved by identifying several osteometric differences that have been related to populational variability. There are some limitations to these identifications that concern separation difficulties especially between female aurochs and male domestic cattle. Recent papers (Prummel and Niekus, 2011; Scheu et al., 2008) discuss such identification problems, and therefore all auroch remains listed in Table 1 could be underestimated.

Auroch remains are described in terms of their frequency based on the number of identified specimens (NISP). In order to make the samples comparable, the proportion of auroch was calculated as a ratio between the species’ NISP and the total number of identified mammal remains of the site.

The statistical analysis was performed using XLSTAT-Pro 7.5.2. In order to reveal the associations of auroch and other mammals in different geographical regions and periods, and at the same time the similarity between these two variables (regions and periods) considering the frequency of auroch, we used correspondence analysis (CA) (Greenacre, 2002). Correspondence analysis represents an efficient approach that can produce results beyond independent analyses of the data. In its simplest form, CA applies to a two-way cross-tabulation, such as the one in Table 2. This table summarizes the frequency of aurochs to all mammals identified in different time periods (rows) and geographic regions (columns). CA allows large tables with many cases and units (such as Table 1) to be simplified. The final aim of CA is to produce a map of this table, where each row and column is represented by a point. The way CA works is similar to principal components analysis (PCA), in that the total variance of the table is defined and then this total is decomposed optimally along so-called ‘principal axes’. For mapping purposes, it is usually hoped that a large percentage of total variance is accounted for by the first two principal axes, thereby allowing the table to be visualized in two dimensions (Greenacre, 2002). Component scores are plotted in two-dimensional space and represent the relationship between row and column variables. The close spatial proximity indicates a close relationship and the greater the distance between two variables (points on the map) reveals a weaker relationship (Van Derwarker, 2010). Two-way ANOVA was used to test the influence of regions and chronological time on aurochs NISP.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Among the animal resources used in the human settlements, aurochs constitute in general a small part. As can be seen in Table 1, archaeozoological assemblages feature variable proportions of auroch remains, and spatial and temporal patterning seems evident.

Of all skeletal remains of Bos primigenius that have been identified in the archaeozoological assemblages, 94.16% of them proceed from Neolithic sites and the fewest from Antiquity (0.18%) and Middle Ages (0.86%) (Figure 2).

caption.p: Distribution of auroch remains (%NISP) in ancient periods (Neolithic: 113 sites; Bronze Age: 24 sites; Iron Age: 27 sites; Antiquity: 8 sites; Middle Ages: 18 sites).

sec.p: Skeletal remains belonging to domestic mammals dominate numerically in all archaeological sites, representing over 60% of all remains identified in each sample, except those from Banat in the Bronze Age. As can be seen in Figures 3 and 4, the trend is towards a diminution in time of auroch frequency. In the archaezoological samples dating from the Neolithic period the remains of auroch represent on average 3.30% of all identified mammal remains, whereas those dating from the Middle Ages represent about 0.22%. The ratio between the other wild mammals hunted and Bos primigenius records the highest values in samples belonging the Antiquity and Middle Ages (Figure 4).

caption.p: Frequency (%) of auroch remains in the archaeozoological samples (Neolithic: 113 sites; Bronze Age: 24 sites; Iron Age: 27 sites; Antiquity: 8 sites; Middle Ages: 18 sites).
NISP ratio: domestic mammals/Bos primigenius/other wild mammals.

sec.p: Results of two-way ANOVA (Table 3) show a significant influence of the variables on sample size of auroch remains (F=3.009; p=0.0042). The coefficient of determination (R2) shows that 67% of the variance can be explained by chronological periods (F=5.067; p=0.013) and less by regions, while interactions between these two factors have no contribution (Type I and III).

tr.td: (b) Type I Sum of Squares analysis.
(c) Type III Sum of Squares analysis.

sec.p: The five major regions of the country exhibit not only differences and coincidences but also variability at the local level in the importance of hunted auroch, the maximum values being recorded for southern Romania (Wallachia) in Neolithic – on average 5.7% (Figure 4). These differences could reflect adaptations to the environment, in accordance with the large presence of the domestic form (cattle) in the area. More intensive hunting activity in Neolithic Wallachia could also be another explanation for the higher proportion of auroch bones, especially considering that the frequency for other wild mammals is also largest here.

CA of data yields the graphical display shown in Figure 5. It has two sets of symbols that correspond to the two types of variables (columns: regions and rows: periods). Although the positions of two sets of symbols with respect to each other are not directly comparable and should be interpreted with caution, in interpretation given by Greenacre (1984) for this type of analysis every point of the two sets will lie in the neighborhood of the unit in which the profile is prominent between the row-frequency profiles.

caption.p: Correspondence analysis of regions and periods (bi-dimensional representation).

sec.p: In terms of the analysis conducted for the data, 88.52% of the variance is explained in the first two axes (Table 4). The component scores for rows and columns are listed in Table 5.

caption.p: Component scores for row and columns units.

sec.p: In Figure 5, the first axis (F1), which explains 49.52% of the variance, separates Antiquity on the right side of the graph from the other periods and Dobrudja from the rest of regions, while on the left side of map it will be a cluster that includes the other variables. The second axis (F2) explains 38.99% of the total inertia and it does approximate the same separation inside regions and periods. The association between these variables (Antiquity and Dobrudja) is obvious, and the explanation for that distribution on that map is the fact that the most bones dating from Antiquity were found in archaeological sites of Dobrudja. A few bones from the same period were found also in Banat, but the higher frequencies of remains of this species in other time periods places this variable closer to the variables Bronze Age, Iron Ages or Neolithic. Very low frequency of auroch remains in the sites dating from Antiquity period explains the position on the map of this variable versus the Neolithic. Comparable frequencies of auroch in the Transylvania and Banat regions are a clarification for the similar scores obtained of these two variables. Proximity between the Banat, Transylvania and Wallachia points and the Neolithic point could be interpreted by the higher frequencies of Neolithic remains found in these three regions. Also, the highest frequency of Middle Ages auroch from the Banat region confirm the position of these two variables on the map.

It is assumed that anthropic pressure became more intense towards the first half of the 2nd millennium ad, generating changes at the level of vegetation cover that the faunal spectra translate into a gradual reduction through time in the distribution not only of auroch but also of other wild species, such as beaver, red deer or bear (Bejenaru et al., 2010). An excess of hunting, combined with forest clearance and other environmental pressures brought about by rising numbers of human population must also lie at the root of this reduction in the distribution ranges, later resulting in the extinction of the auroch. The last identifications of auroch have been archaeozoologically documented in Moldavia (i.e. Siret, Baia), and Transylvania (Simleul Silvaniei) for the 14th–15th centuries. A singular horn core has been also identified in a late Medieval pit (16th–17th centuries) of the Princely Court of Suceava in Moldavia (Haimovici, 2005). During the Middle Ages several restrictions on the hunting of wild species, including auroch, were introduced, as the their number within the atchaeozoological samples is rather low (Bejenaru, 2009).

However, the anthropic pressure became more intense towards the Middle Ages, generating changes at the level of vegetation cover that the faunal spectra translate into a gradual reduction through time in the distribution of several species, including auroch. An excess of hunting, combined with forest clearance and other environmental pressures brought about by rising numbers of the human population must also lie at the extinction of auroch.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present synthesis focused on Romanian auroch identifications during the Holocene reveals, first of all, that hunting of the species was a regular practice, whose economic importance shifted both in time and space. Most of the analysed sites exhibit a rather low proportion of auroch, but there is probably a general underestimation because of difficulties in the separation of auroch/cattle. As a game animal, the auroch generally diminish in the archaeozoological records from all regions since Neolithic to Middle Ages. The sites from the Neolithic period in Walachia (southern Romania) evidence a relative intensification of auroch hunting, suggesting a larger contribution of this species to the diet. As a game animal, auroch diminish in the archaeozoological records from Middle Ages in almost all regions, with the exception of a few samples from Banat.

Under anthropic pressure (excessive hunting and forest clearance) that became more intense towards the Middle Ages, the auroch population underwent a gradual reduction through time and space in the territory of Romania.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This study was supported by the Romanian research programs CNCSIS-PN II Idei_2116/2008 and POSDRU/89/1.5/S/49944.
